headline.main: The Fit Tend to Fidget, and Biology May Be Why, a Study Says

docs.abstract: Study at Mayo Clinic finds that overweight people tend to sit, while lean ones have trouble holding still and spend two hours or more each day on their feet, pacing around and fidgeting; difference translates into about 350 calories daily; difference in activity levels may be biological and inborn, result of genetically determined levels of brain chemicals that govern person's tendency to move around; researchers believe it is predisposition to be inactive that leads to obesity, rather than other way around; findings are considered hopeful for overweight people who, with relatively simple behavior changes that would add activity, might find it easier to lose weight (M)
docs.lead_paragraph: Overweight people have a tendency to sit, while lean ones have trouble holding still and spend two hours more a day on their feet, pacing around and fidgeting, researchers are reporting in findings published today. The difference translates into about 350 calories a day, enough to produce a weight loss of 30 to 40 pounds in one year without trips to the gym -- if only heavy people could act more restless, like thin ones.
docs.snippet: Overweight people have a tendency to sit, while lean ones have trouble holding still, and the difference in activity levels may be inborn, researchers suggest.

headline.main: Study Prompts New Precautions for Diabetics

docs.abstract: New British study suggests people with Type 1 or juvenile diabetes should follow same advice as other diabetics about smoking, weight gain and blood pressure; until now, they have been told that controlling blood sugar is all they can do to prevent nerve damage that can lead to amputation (M)
docs.lead_paragraph: For decades, people with juvenile diabetes have been told that controlling their blood sugar is all they can do to prevent nerve damage that can lead to the amputation of a foot or leg. But a large new British study suggests they should follow the same advice given to other diabetics: Don't smoke, and watch your weight and blood pressure.
docs.snippet: A new study suggests that people with juvenile diabetes should follow the same advice given to other diabetics: Don't smoke, and watch your weight and blood pressure.

docs.abstract: Dr Ian Thompson, University of Texas Health Science Center researcher, leads study on effectiveness of test to determine prostate cancer; study, published in journal Cancer, finds that obese men have PSA test readings that average one-third lower than men of normal weight; hold that lower readings could delay diagnosis; drawing (S)
docs.lead_paragraph: Obesity appears to skew the results of the most common test used to detect prostate cancer, a study released yesterday concluded. According to the study, which was released online and will be published in March in the journal Cancer, earlier research has shown that obese men have a lower survival rate for prostate cancer and that their cancer tends to be diagnosed in more advanced forms.
docs.snippet: Obesity appears to skew the results of the most common test used to detect prostate cancer, a new study concluded.

headline.main: Paying a Price for Doughnuts, Burgers and Pizza

docs.abstract: Devastating results of poor diet, no exercise and lots of stress concerns health advocates in poor communities across New York City; diabetes is fourth leading cause of death among young men and women in poor neighborhoods, and heart disease and obesity claim more lives than ever; Health People community education group in South Bronx tries to educate people about their diets that often contain abundances of calories and fat from fast food; says that healthy foods are difficult to find in area, even in grocery stores; Dr Hal Strelnick, expert in family and social medicine, says he has seen increasing number of young people suffering from obesity, high cholesterol and high blood pressure; says levels do not have to be above critical to kill, and that combination of all them at borderline is just as dangerous; photo (M)
docs.lead_paragraph: Hunger -- or insanity -- could lead someone to eat his way around the intersection of East 149th Street and Southern Boulevard in the South Bronx. From the bakery filled with sugary cakes, past the Latin restaurant selling curled slabs of fried pork skin, past the Dunkin' Donuts and on to Popeyes Chicken and Biscuits. Just in case, a pizzeria and a White Castle beckon from nearby blocks, too. Towering over this strip is a giant mural for what by default is the only light thing around: Coors Light.
docs.snippet: The devastating results of poor diet, no exercise and lots of stress are increasingly scaring health advocates in poor communities.

headline.main: Courting the Lazy and the Klutzy

docs.abstract: Article on some of vast array of sports gear, from battery-powered skateboards to practice baseballs engineered to curve when thrown, that sporting goods industry is introducing in effort to induce Americans to become more active with less effort; photos; chart (M)
docs.lead_paragraph: MOST people aren't inspired to perspire. And no part of American retailing is more determined than the sporting goods industry to see that inertia, no matter how comfortable, doesn't dominate consumers' lives. But the makers of sports gear know all too well the public's couch-potato tendencies. ''Obesity in America: It's a Huge Problem,'' screamed the headline on an industry report distributed last week at the annual convention of the Sporting Goods Manufacturers Association in Orlando, Fla., attended by 40,000 industry professionals.
docs.snippet: Companies are introducing a vast array of products aimed at couch potatoes.
